1:
# Introduction

In the following, we briefly give an introduction to the interface of the polyhedral playground.

It allows you to:
- run python programs in a [Jypter](jupyter.org)-style shell
- provides a python interface to perform loop modeling with Presburger Sets and Relations
- visualize Presburger Sets and Relations

[Markdown]

Introduction

In the following, we briefly give an introduction to the interface of the polyhedral playground.

It allows you to:

  • run python programs in a Jypter-style shell
  • provides a python interface to perform loop modeling with Presburger Sets and Relations
  • visualize Presburger Sets and Relations
2:
## Running Python in the Browser

This is a normal REPL style notebook. The input languages is python. Multi-line python code can be inserted by simply typing `Enter`. A statement is executed by typing `Shift+Enter`.

### Exercise:

Type the python expression `print(1 + 1)` and execute it.

[Markdown]

Running Python in the Browser

This is a normal REPL style notebook. The input languages is python. Multi-line python code can be inserted by simply typing Enter. A statement is executed by typing Shift+Enter.

Exercise:

Type the python expression print(1 + 1) and execute it.
4:
## Navigating the REPL

Several commands are available to navigate the notebook:

- `Arrow Up` (↑) moves one line up within an input field. At the beginning of an input field, it moves to the previous input field.
- `Arrow Down` (↓) moves one line down within an input field. At the end of an input field, it moves to the next input field.
- `Tab` moves to the next input field.
- `Shift + Tab` moves to the previous input field.

[Markdown]

Navigating the REPL

Several commands are available to navigate the notebook:

  • Arrow Up (↑) moves one line up within an input field. At the beginning of an input field, it moves to the previous input field.
  • Arrow Down (↓) moves one line down within an input field. At the end of an input field, it moves to the next input field.
  • Tab moves to the next input field.
  • Shift + Tab moves to the previous input field.
5:
## Annotating your code An input field that starts with `#` is interpreted as text. It is not executed as python code, but instead formatted as [Markdown](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet). Markdown input can be edited by clicking on the `[Markdown]` link, or by navigating to an input field using Tab or Arrows. Simple markdown intro: ### Headers \# Header 1 \## Header 2 \### Header 3 ### Highlight \**Italic Text*\* \*\***Bold Text**\** ### Code ``` ``` print(1+1) ``` ``` [Markdown]

Annotating your code

An input field that starts with # is interpreted as text. It is not executed as python code, but instead formatted as Markdown. Markdown input can be edited by clicking on the [Markdown] link, or by navigating to an input field using Tab or Arrows.

Simple markdown intro:

Headers

# Header 1
## Header 2
### Header 3

Highlight

*Italic Text*
**Bold Text**

Code

 ```  
 print(1+1)  
 ```
markdown
6:
## Solutions

An input field starting with `#!Solution` can be used to provide solutions to an exercise. Its content is hidden by default and inserted only after the user clicks `Solution`. It can only be edited in `Constructor Mode` (see navigation menu).

```
#!Solution
print("This is the solution")
```

[Markdown]

Solutions

An input field starting with #!Solution can be used to provide solutions to an exercise. Its content is hidden by default and inserted only after the user clicks Solution. It can only be edited in Constructor Mode (see navigation menu).

#!Solution
print("This is the solution")
